column4: if you want to compile a kernel for write access I'm sure its possible
i believe it is ufs (unix file system)

http://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/bsd-17/mount-ufs-partitions-not-slices-from-linux-etcfstab-425047/#post2217856    has an fstab example, you can also use the entry rearranged to form a mount command'
seems to be a recognised fs to the kernel
yeah just trying to do it from the GUI isn't permitted it looks like.
scsi disks are called what in /dev ?
you'll need to run the gui with gksudo, i'd add anentry in fstab to automount it
this mount will only be in there for 2 minutes then i'm putting another one on. I can make it so the GUI can auto mount ufs whenever I put a disk in that is that format?
the gconf should mount it, or you will av to manually mount again
lol so you know i know nothing about any of this:)
what do you mean? i'm looking through dmesg and its telling me that ufs was compiled with read-only support.
Ill go a different path before that:)
ah got it working, ufs support is in a module instead of in the kernel or... something lol
